title: apostles
comment: Appointed representatives, deriving authority and responsibilities from the person or group represented. The word refers especially to Jesus Christ's twelve disciples and also to Paul. Scripture identifies the functions of apostles and their authority, which is derived directly from Jesus Christ.

children.title: apostles, designation of
children.comment: An apostle is one who is ``sent'' by Jesus Christ. The word is used to refer especially to the inner circle of Christ's twelve disciples, but is also used specifically to refer to Paul, who was commissioned as an apostle by the risen Christ. The term is also applied more loosely to certain other leading Christians in the NT period.

primaryrefs.comment: This is the only place where the word ``apostle'' is used of Jesus Christ, though many passages refer to him as ``sent''
Jesus Christ, as God's ``sent one'', sets the standard and pattern for all who are likewise ``sent'' (i.e., for all apostolic ministry).

children.title: The twelve apostles called by Jesus Christ

primaryrefs.comment: ``the Twelve'' is frequently used to designate these specially chosen disciples. The number twelve evokes the twelve tribes of Israel.

children.title: Their commissioning by the risen Christ

seealsos.comment: The symbolic number (twelve) is thus preserved.

children.title: The qualifications for being an apostle

secondaryrefs.comment: Although not one of the Twelve, Paul saw the risen Christ and was directly commissioned by him, sent especially to the Gentiles

primaryrefs.comment: In Paul's case the sense of title or office and the ministry and function virtually coincide. He is an apostle both because he has seen and been commissioned by the risen Christ and because he functioned as an apostle by founding churches.

children.title: apostles, function of
children.comment: In the NT apostles are servants, first of Jesus Christ and then of the church. Apostolic service embraces a wide range of specific functions.
